answer:
1. Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis:  
   • Frame 1: The oncoming black sedan is fairly far in the distance. No obvious illumination is visible on either front corner or in the headlights.  
   • Frame 2: Still no discernible flashing or amber light on the front corners; headlights appear off in the daytime.  
   • Frame 3: The oncoming vehicle is closer, but neither side shows an active turn signal (no bright or blinking amber), and both headlights appear off.  
   • Frame 4: The sedan is even nearer, and there remains no sign of a left or right signal (which would glow amber) and no sign of four‐way flashers (dual amber signals at the same time).  
   • Frame 5: Immediately before passing the dashcam, nothing suggests a turn signal or headlight is on; no amber or white glow at the corners or headlights.  

2. Contextual Reasoning:  
   Because signals (left, right, or hazards) are typically amber and quite visible even in daylight, and because headlights likewise create a clear white glow or reflection, the complete absence of any such lighting in each frame strongly indicates the oncoming car has no lights activated.

3. Match to Answer Choices:  
   • A. No lights are on – consistent with all five frames.  
   • B. Left turn light is on – contradicted by the lack of any amber light.  
   • C. Right turn light is on – likewise no visible amber indication.  
   • D. Hazard lights are on – would appear as flashing ambers on both sides; not observed.  

4. Provide the Best Answer:  
<answer>A. No lights are on.</answer>
